Mar 31, 2018 Dee rated it liked it
The book was a little hard to get into, slow, but things start to heat up soon. This novel reveals the dark side of society and shows how far a parent may go to protect their child.

It's a summer's evening in Amsterdam, and 2 couples (2 brothers and their wives) meet at a fashionable restaurant for dinner. Between mouthfuls of food and over the polite scrapings of cutlery, the conversation remains a gentle hum of polite discourse - the banality of work, the triviality of the holidays. But behind The book was a little hard to get into, slow, but things start to heat up soon. This novel reveals the dark side of society and shows how far a parent may go to protect their child.

It's a summer's evening in Amsterdam, and 2 couples (2 brothers and their wives) meet at a fashionable restaurant for dinner. Between mouthfuls of food and over the polite scrapings of cutlery, the conversation remains a gentle hum of polite discourse - the banality of work, the triviality of the holidays. But behind the empty words, terrible things need to be said, and with every forced smile and every new course, the knives are being sharpened.

Each couple has a fifteen-year-old son. The two boys are united by their accountability for a single horrific act; an act that has triggered a police investigation and shattered the comfortable, insulated worlds of their families. As the dinner reaches its culinary climax, the conversation finally touches on their children. ...more

Mar 07, 2018 Natalie Thomas rated it liked it
**this post contains spoilers**

I loved that "The Dinner" touched upon so many different issues: privilege, capital punishment, vigilantism, politics, family dynamics and discord, cultural differences and social etiquette. I thought the story progressed at the perfect pace. No points felt belabored and I never felt that Mr. Koch was using this novel as his own personal soapbox. There were points during the meal that I felt as tense as the characters, as annoyed by the waiter and manager, as **this post contains spoilers**

I loved that "The Dinner" touched upon so many different issues: privilege, capital punishment, vigilantism, politics, family dynamics and discord, cultural differences and social etiquette. I thought the story progressed at the perfect pace. No points felt belabored and I never felt that Mr. Koch was using this novel as his own personal soapbox. There were points during the meal that I felt as tense as the characters, as annoyed by the waiter and manager, as scared as the children and as angry as Paul.

I enjoyed this book a lot but I had a few issues. Could be because I'm a nosy person. These three things left me unfulfilled:

1) not knowing what Claire's hospitalization was caused by
2) not knowing what mental illness afflicted Paul
3) not knowing what happened to Beau ...more

Jun 17, 2017 Sarah rated it liked it
Shelves: 2017-reads, psychological-thriller
This is definitely a book you need to read with a book club or a friend because you're going to want to discuss it. It ended up being a lot more complex than I initially thought and I have so many questions. What starts out as an uncomfortable dinner between two brothers and their wives evolves into something dark and sinister. I'm anxious to see this story played out on the big screen!

I had a hard time rating this book because even though I thought it was well-written, I didn't like any of the This is definitely a book you need to read with a book club or a friend because you're going to want to discuss it. It ended up being a lot more complex than I initially thought and I have so many questions. What starts out as an uncomfortable dinner between two brothers and their wives evolves into something dark and sinister. I'm anxious to see this story played out on the big screen!

I had a hard time rating this book because even though I thought it was well-written, I didn't like any of the characters and I was bored with the storyline until about halfway through because I didn't know where the story was going. That said, I'm glad I read it, but I can't exactly say that I enjoyed it. ...more

Mar 21, 2020 Alesha rated it liked it
Shelves: aty-52-2020
3üåü... I think. I'm honestly not sure how to rate this book.

Every single character in this book is vile. But, I found myself intrigued enough to continue reading, whereas many other books with such unlikable characters have caused me to lose interest or just have no opinion whatsoever as to where the plot went.

I found more than a few of the "twists" fairly predictable though, and I wouldn't necessarily classify this as a thriller. Much of the internal dialogue of our main narrator seemed to drag 3üåü... I think. I'm honestly not sure how to rate this book.

Every single character in this book is vile. But, I found myself intrigued enough to continue reading, whereas many other books with such unlikable characters have caused me to lose interest or just have no opinion whatsoever as to where the plot went.

I found more than a few of the "twists" fairly predictable though, and I wouldn't necessarily classify this as a thriller. Much of the internal dialogue of our main narrator seemed to drag on at times, although I can see why the thoughts of the narrator were important to his characterization.

Wouldn't recommend as a thriller or suspense rec, but if you still find yourself intrigued by this book (as did I despite the low average Goodreads rating) then I'd say give it a go! ...more

Dec 19, 2017 Gary Lawrence rated it liked it
Shelves: audible-com-audiobook, review-written
Three stars might seem harsh for a well written book with a fantastic Audible narrator and an important theme. It's three stars because I disliked it intensely. The characters were hateful and the situation in the restaurant contrived. The parents are supposed to be demonstrating the extent to which they will go to protect their child but come across as completely selfish, self centred rather than have the self sacrifice that characterises parental love. I read for enjoyment or to learn Three stars might seem harsh for a well written book with a fantastic Audible narrator and an important theme. It's three stars because I disliked it intensely. The characters were hateful and the situation in the restaurant contrived. The parents are supposed to be demonstrating the extent to which they will go to protect their child but come across as completely selfish, self centred rather than have the self sacrifice that characterises parental love. I read for enjoyment or to learn something (about myself or life). All I learned from this book was to very, very careful next time in Holland. ...more

Sep 03, 2017 Sarina M rated it liked it
Shelves: a
This book was recommended to me by a friend who said it was a page turner and is really exciting, which is absolutely true. My biggest complaint with this book is that I did not like any of the characters in the story, which makes it hard for me to care about the characters enough to be interested in what happens to them. Apart from that, I like the way this book is set up, where the entire story takes place over one night. There are flashbacks to give background information. I also like books This book was recommended to me by a friend who said it was a page turner and is really exciting, which is absolutely true. My biggest complaint with this book is that I did not like any of the characters in the story, which makes it hard for me to care about the characters enough to be interested in what happens to them. Apart from that, I like the way this book is set up, where the entire story takes place over one night. There are flashbacks to give background information. I also like books that take place in other countries, this one takes place in the Netherlands. The book started out slow and then kept building momentum right up till the end. ...more

May 28, 2019 Justin Brendel rated it liked it
Serge and Phil, brothers, are having dinner with their wives at a fancy restaurant. Typical chatter, and then, things take a turn as they discuss their sons.

This book felt promising for me, but about mid way through the book, it derailed and I felt slowed down. The dialogue seemed hokey in what is equivalent to a shifty eye of a suspect in a tv mystery.

Relationships between spouses, but also parents vs. children, are analyzed and flushed out. Good premise, but just fell a bit flat for me.

Jan 24, 2019 Dara Salley rated it liked it
This book was four-stars for the enjoyment I had reading it, but dropped to three-stars due to the ending. When an author presents a story that is so brutal, so suspenseful, so infuriating, I think he owes the reader a little catharsis at the end. Koch vehemently denies the reader this catharsis. I appreciate the literary merit of this, and its probably more truthful to life. There is a lack of satisfaction in the neat-as-a-bow, good guys get married, bad guys get punished kind of ending, as This book was four-stars for the enjoyment I had reading it, but dropped to three-stars due to the ending. Aug 18, 2017 Simone rated it liked it
Shelves: 2017-read, audiobooks
I read this for a book club, and it made a great book club book because there was a lot to discuss. I wouldn't read too much about it before you read it, as the book twists and turns along the way, and the surprises are half the fun. Some people really hate it because the characters are terrible people, but I think that's sort of the point. We're all terrible animals somewhere just beneath the surface.

Mar 19, 2018 Ms.Hulke rated it liked it
I found this book just ok...I want to give it 2.5 stars instead of 3. I kept wanting to read and find out what happened, which is a plus, but I found the dialogue to be very forced and fake and there was nothing about the characters I found remotely redeeming. The book took dark and twisty turns that I was not anticipating. I think maybe my expectations were too high. I did enjoy the way the plot was organizized like a dinner course. While the book overall was not my favorite, others may enjoy I found this book just ok...I want to give it 2.5 stars instead of 3. While the book overall was not my favorite, others may enjoy it, particularly those who like darker plot twists with a lot of dialogue. ...more

Jul 17, 2018 Jodi Tooke rated it liked it
A dark tale that reveals the rotten worst of a privileged family. The novel cleverly follows the progression of a meal for which two brothers meet with their wives to discuss a "family" problem. Suspenseful and unbelievably frank in dealing with a rich, entitled class.

Dec 31, 2017 Roanne rated it liked it
I liked the book. I did. It was good-- to some extent, that is. I've never read any book (as far as I can remember) that gave me read rage as much as this one did. The characters are unlikable and extremely anger-inducing, I wanted to throw my phone against a wall and call it a day. But I kept turning the page, so that has got to mean something, right?

Sep 13, 2018 Dibyajyoti Kalita rated it liked it
The Dinner promises to take you on an enthralling ride. But it tends to get a little too convoluted if you are not paying close attention. It is a wonderfully dark tale of human miseries and desperation and has been written in a way to keep the readers' intrigue built all the time.

Aug 24, 2017 Toni FGMAMTC rated it liked it
Shelves: psychological-thriller, psychology
3.5 stars

I don't know what to say about this book. Everyone in it seems to be crazy. I didn't know what was going on at first. Now that I've finished I don't know how to rate it. It's a weird story, but it's uniquely weird. I just don't know. This book is an experience for sure.

Aug 30, 2018 Heather rated it liked it
I wanted to like this one. What I gathered is that the individuals in the book have some serious mental disorders. I know all families have skeletons in the closet, but, my, oh, my, this family takes the cake! If you want to read a book to make you feel better about your own family, this one is for you!
